docs.title: Linux Command Line Training
docs.text:
Welcome to the Linux Command Line Training course. This comprehensive program is designed for new hires and junior engineers seeking to master the Linux command line interface.

Course Overview

Master the Linux command line through hands-on exercises, practical labs, and real-world scenarios. This course focuses on building strong foundational skills while introducing advanced concepts used in enterprise environments.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
Prerequisites

  • Access to a Linux environment (local or virtual machine)
  • Basic computer literacy
  • Text editor familiarity
  • Basic understanding of operating systems

Course Format

  • Self-paced modules
  • Hands-on exercises
  • Practical labs
  • Real-world scenarios
  • Assessment challenges

docs.title: Module 1: Command Line Basics
docs.text: Learn the fundamentals of the command line interface, including basic navigation, commands, and shell concepts. Start Module 1

docs.title: Module 2: File System Navigation
docs.text: Master the Linux file system hierarchy, file operations, and understanding permissions. Start Module 2

docs.title: Module 3: Text Processing
docs.text: Learn essential text processing tools, editors, and regular expressions. Start Module 3

docs.title: Module 4: Advanced Command Line
docs.text: Deep dive into piping, redirection, and process management. Start Module 4

docs.title: Module 5: System Administration
docs.text: Understand user management, package management, and system services. Start Module 5

docs.title: Module 6: Networking
docs.text: Master networking tools, remote access, and network troubleshooting. Start Module 6

docs.title: Module 7: Advanced Topics
docs.text: Explore shell scripting, security, and performance optimization. Start Module 7

docs.title: Hands-on Learning
docs.text: Each module includes practical exercises and labs that reinforce theoretical concepts through real-world applications.

docs.title: Progressive Skill Building
docs.text: Modules build upon each other, ensuring a strong foundation before advancing to more complex topics.

docs.title: Assessments
docs.text: Regular knowledge checks and practical assessments help verify your understanding and mastery of concepts.

docs.title: Real-world Scenarios
docs.text: Practice with common enterprise scenarios and troubleshooting challenges.

docs.title: Understanding the Command Line Interface
docs.text: The command line interface (CLI) is your direct line of communication with the Linux operating system. Unlike graphical interfaces that use icons and menus, the CLI uses text commands to perform operations.

docs.title: What is the Command Line?
docs.text: The command line is a text interface for your computer. It's a program that takes in commands and passes them on to the computer's operating system to carry out.

docs.title: Why Use the Command Line?
docs.text:
1. Efficiency

    1. Perform tasks faster than with GUI
    2. Chain commands together
    3. Automate repetitive tasks

  2. Power

    1. Access all system features
    2. More precise control
    3. Advanced functionality

  3. Resource Usage

    1. Uses minimal system resources
    2. Works on all Linux systems
    3. Operates over slow connections

  4. Remote Access

    1. Manage remote systems
    2. Consistent across platforms
    3. Low bandwidth requirement

docs.title: The Terminal
docs.text:
username@hostname:~$

classDiagram
    direction LR
    class username {
        Your login name
    }
    class at["@"]
    class hostname {
        Computer name
    }
    class colon[":"]
    class tilde["~"] {
        Current directory
    }
    class dollar["$"] {
        Command prompt for regular user
    }

    username --> at
    at --> hostname
    hostname --> colon
    colon --> tilde
    tilde --> dollar

docs.title: Command Structure
docs.text:
command [options] [arguments]
Example: 
ls -l /home
- ls is the command - -l is the option - /home is the argument

docs.title: First Commands
docs.text:
Try these basic commands: 

whoami     # Display your username
date       # Show current date/time
pwd        # Print working directory
clear      # Clear the screen

docs.title: Command Options
docs.text:
• Short options: Single letter with dash (-a)
  • Long options: Full word with double dash (--all)
  • Combined options: Multiple short options (-la)

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Be precise with commands
  2. Double-check before executing
  3. Use tab completion
  4. Keep commands simple at first
  5. Practice regularly

docs.title: Common Mistakes to Avoid
docs.text:
• Mixing up upper/lowercase
  • Forgetting spaces between options
  • Using wrong slashes
  • Ignoring error messages

docs.title: Up Next
docs.text:
In the next section, we'll explore terminal basics and learn essential keyboard shortcuts for efficient command line use.

Practice Tip

Take time to practice these basic commands. Muscle memory is important for command line proficiency.

docs.title: Format Structure
docs.text:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>

<body>

<footer>

docs.title: 1. Type (Required)
docs.text: One of the following: - feat: New feature or functionality - fix: Bug fix - docs: Documentation changes - style: Code style/formatting (no code change) - refactor: Code refactoring (no feature/fix) - perf: Performance improvements - test: Adding or modifying tests - chore: Maintenance tasks, dependencies, etc.

docs.title: 2. Scope (Optional)
docs.text: Indicates the section of the codebase affected, e.g.: - Component name - File name - Feature area - Module name

docs.title: 3. Subject (Required)
docs.text:
• Use imperative mood ("Add" not "Added" or "Adds")
  • No period at the end
  • Maximum 72 characters
  • Start with lowercase letter

docs.title: 4. Body (Optional)
docs.text:
• Separate from subject with blank line
  • Explain what and why vs. how
  • Wrap at 72 characters
  • Use imperative mood

docs.title: 5. Footer (Optional)
docs.text:
• Reference issues, tickets, breaking changes
  • One issue reference per line
  • Breaking changes must start with "BREAKING CHANGE:"

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Simple commit: 

feat(auth): add password reset functionality

With body: 

fix(api): prevent timeout on long-running queries

Implement request timeout handling to avoid server overload.
Requests exceeding 30s will return 408 status code.

Closes #123

Breaking change: 

feat(api): change authentication method

Replace token-based auth with OAuth2.

BREAKING CHANGE: `authenticate()` now requires client_id parameter
Closes #456

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
1. Each commit should contain related changes only
  2. Test before committing
  3. No comments in commit messages
  4. Write meaningful messages that explain WHY
  5. Use present tense imperative mood

docs.title: Message Formula
docs.text: Test your subject line with: "If applied, this commit will..." - Good: "If applied, this commit will add user authentication" - Bad: "If applied, this commit will added user authentication"

docs.title: Introduction to Linux Command Line Training
docs.text: Welcome to the Linux Command Line Training course. This comprehensive program is designed to transform you from a command line novice into a proficient Linux user. Whether you're new to Linux or looking to enhance your skills, this course provides the foundation needed for effective system administration and operation.

docs.title: Course Overview
docs.text: This training program focuses on practical, hands-on experience with the Linux command line interface (CLI). You'll learn essential commands, understand system concepts, and develop the skills needed to effectively manage Linux systems.

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
• Navigate the Linux file system confidently
  • Manage files and directories effectively
  • Process and manipulate text data
  • Understand user management and permissions
  • Work with system processes
  • Configure networking
  • Write shell scripts for automation
  • Implement security best practices

docs.title: Why Command Line?
docs.text:
While graphical interfaces are user-friendly, the command line offers several significant advantages:

  1. Efficiency: Accomplish tasks faster than with GUI tools
  2. Automation: Create scripts to automate repetitive tasks
  3. Remote Access: Manage systems remotely with minimal bandwidth
  4. Precision: Execute commands with exact parameters
  5. Resource Usage: Operate with minimal system resources
  6. System Control: Access advanced features not available in GUIs

docs.title: Module-Based Learning
docs.text:
Each module builds upon previous knowledge, providing a structured learning path:

  1. Command Line Basics: Foundation of command line usage
  2. File System Navigation: Understanding and managing files
  3. Text Processing: Working with file contents
  4. Advanced Command Line: Pipes, redirections, and job control
  5. System Administration: User and service management
  6. Networking: Configuration and troubleshooting
  7. Advanced Topics: Scripting and security

docs.title: Learning Components
docs.text:
Each module includes:

  • Theoretical Concepts: Understanding the "why" behind commands
  • Practical Examples: Real-world usage scenarios
  • Hands-on Exercises: Practice what you've learned
  • Lab Assignments: Apply knowledge to realistic situations
  • Knowledge Checks: Verify your understanding

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Before beginning the Linux Command Line Training course, you'll need to have access to a Linux environment. For Windows users, we recommend using Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) with Ubuntu. Follow these installation steps:

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text:
• Windows 10 version 2004 and higher (Build 19041 and higher) or Windows 11
  • Administrator access to your Windows system
  • At least 4GB of free disk space

docs.title: 1. Enable Windows Subsystem for Linux
docs.text:
1. Enable required Windows features:

    • Press Windows + R
    • Type "optionalfeatures.exe"
    • Press Enter
    • Enable:
      • Windows Subsystem for Linux
      • Virtual Machine Platform
      • SMB Direct (if available)
    • Click OK and restart when prompted

    Note

    These features are required for WSL to function properly. Your system will need to restart after enabling them.

docs.title: 2. Install Ubuntu
docs.text:
1. Open Microsoft Store
  2. Search for "Ubuntu"

  3. Choose a version:

    • Ubuntu (latest version)
    • Ubuntu 22.04.5 LTS (Recommended)
    • Ubuntu 20.04.6 LTS
    • Ubuntu 18.04.6 LTS

    Tip

    We recommend using the LTS (Long Term Support) version for stability and extended support.

docs.title: 3. Initial Setup
docs.text:
1. Launch Ubuntu from the Start menu
  2. Wait for initial installation to complete

  3. Create your UNIX user account: 

    Enter new UNIX username: your_username
New password: your_password
Retype new password: your_password

    Warning

    • The password will not be visible as you type
    • Choose a username that is lowercase and simple
    • Use a strong password that you can remember

docs.title: Username Guidelines
docs.text:
• Use lowercase letters only
  • Avoid special characters
  • Keep it simple and memorable
  • Doesn't need to match Windows username

docs.title: Password Guidelines
docs.text:
• Use a strong combination of:
    • Uppercase letters
    • Lowercase letters
    • Numbers
    • Special characters
  • Minimum 8 characters recommended
  • Store securely

docs.title: System Maintenance
docs.text:
• Update Windows regularly
  • Keep WSL features current
  • Monitor available disk space
  • Regular system updates

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Run these commands in your Ubuntu terminal: 

# Check Linux kernel version
uname -a

# Verify Ubuntu version
lsb_release -a

# Test basic commands
pwd
ls
whoami

docs.title: Initial System Update
docs.text:
After verification, update your system: 

# Update package list and upgrade installed packages
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade

Troubleshooting

If you encounter issues:

  1. Verify Windows version compatibility

  2. Check Windows Features are properly enabled

  3. Run wsl --update in PowerShell as administrator

  4. Consult official documentation

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After completing the installation and setup:

  1. Review the course structure

  2. Familiarize yourself with the terminal

  3. Proceed to Module 1: Command Line Basics

Ready to Begin

Once you've completed these prerequisites, you're ready to start the course. If you encounter any issues, please consult the troubleshooting section or reach out for assistance.
